Commitment to Students and Student Learn.Effective Classroom Strategies:
The Junior Classroom

The atmosphere that you create in your classroom can have a huge impact on the emotional, social, physical and intellectual development of your junior students. A well-organized and thoughtfully designed classroom will promote positive attitudes toward school and learning. Classrooms with this atmosphere also enable teachers to observe, support and meet learning needs of each student.

Effective Classroom Strategies Discussion Post

Review the ministry guides, watch video clips shared, look at the ministry website for information and locate articles on the effective junior classroom. From this information, create a list of 8-10 essential strategies.

  1. Use pictures, graphics and storyboards.
    When teachers use pictures and graphics more often, students write with more detail, retain more information, and get better grades on written work across the curriculum.
  2. Provide competitive learning opportunities.
    Competitive learning includes classroom debates, content-related games, and goal-oriented activities.
  3. Let students choose some of their reading and writing themselves.
    Regularly including nontraditional materials, such as graphic novels, magazines, and comic books, increases engagement in reading and improves writing.
  4. Move around the classroom as you teach.
    Physical movement increases engagement, while also being able to monitor progress and keep disruptions at a minimum.
  5. Allow students to move around as needed in classrooms.
    This strategy is especially useful when reading or writing—when certain students twitch, tap their feet, stand up, or pace, they are often learning better than if they sit still.
  6. Use hand signals and other non-verbal gestures.
    Hand signals such as holding one hand in the air and wait for them to put their hand up as well as well as non-verbal gestures such as flicking the lights off and on once can be beneficial in getting your students’ attention quickly and efficiently.
  7. Address behaviour problems quickly and wisely.
    A problem between two students can quickly escalate from a molehill to a mountain, so it’s a good idea to solve any issues quickly before they get out of hand. As for handling the problem wisely, bring the students away from the rest of the class and never accuse the child of anything.
  8. Use your normal and natural voice.
    Avoid raising your voice to get your students’ attention as you are more likely to lose your voice and students will often mimic the voice level you use. Also, use different tones of voice depending on what you are requesting of the students (ex - directions vs question).
Commitment to Students and Student Learn.Implementing Principles of Assessment:
The Seven Fundamental Principles of Assessment, Evaluation and Reporting

According to Growing Success,

to ensure that assessment, evaluation, and reporting are valid and reliable, and they they lead to the improvement of learning for all students, teachers use practices and procedures that:

  • are fair, transparent, and equitable for all students;
  • support all students, including those with special education needs, those who are learning the language of instruction, and those who are First Nation, Métis, or Inuit;
  • are carefully planned to relate to the curriculum expectations and learning goals and, as much as possible, to the interests, learning styles and preference, needs, and experiences of all students;
  • are communicated clearly to students and parents at the beginning of the school year or course and at other appropriate points throughout the school year or course;
  • are ongoing, varied in nature, and administered over a period of time to provide multiple opportunities for students to demonstrate the full range of their learning;
  • provide ongoing descriptive feedback that is clear, specific, meaningful, and timely to support improved learning and achievement;
  • develop students’ self-assessment skills to enable them to assess their own learning, set specific goals and plan next steps for their learning.

Principles of Assessment Discussion Post

Read the resources below and reflect on the Seven Fundamental Principles of Assessment. Then select three principles of assessment and evaluation and suggest practical ways of implementing them in the junior classroom.

Resources:

  • Growing Success (pg 6, 15-26, 27-36)
  • Peer Feedback Sample #1
  • Peer Feedback Sample #2

I chose the following three (3) principles of assessment to discuss.

  1. provide ongoing descriptive feedback that is clear, specific, meaningful, and timely to support improved learning and achievement

    What I find effective is to group students together who received similar assessment notes and then have a conference with these students. Grouping students who would benefit from similar suggestions can reduce the amount of time you have to spend discussing the feedback. I believe that if you are consistent and clear with your feedback, your students will better understand and predict your expectations.

  2. are carefully planned to relate to the curriculum expectations and learning goals and, as much as possible, to the interests, learning styles and preference, needs, and experiences of all students

    Once you’ve chosen the expectation that you’d like to assess, create a few assignments that students can choose from to demonstrate their knowledge. Giving students a choice between different assessments makes it easier to engage them and also allows them to gravitate towards a preference that suits them.

  3. are communicated clearly to students and parents at the beginning of the school year or course and at other appropriate points throughout the school year or course

    It is important to keep communication up throughout the year in order to ensure that your students and their parents know what to expect. To apply this principle, teachers can implement the following means of communication:

    • send home a monthly newsletter
    • use agendas to communicate with parents
    • have student conferences to help them assess their own learning
    • post expectation charts around the classroom
    • when giving an assignment, have the class discuss what would make them successful
    • call parents periodically
    • hand back assessments in an appropriate time frame

Inclusive Literature Discussion Post

Create a list of three storybooks that acknoledge and embrace diversity in all its forms (eg. multicultualism, gender stereotypes, etc.) that could be used in the classroom for a lesson (eg. as a read aloud or as a shared reading lesson). Include the following for each book in your list:

  • The title, author, and grade level of the book
  • A synopsis (1-2 sentences)
  • A description of hte issues addressed ad the relevance of the book for the class (1-2 sentences)

  1. Esperanza Rising by Pam Munoz Ryan

    Grade Level: 4+

    Synopsis: It is 1930, and Esperanza is watching the workers on her father’s huge ranch harvest the grapes. Esperanza doesn’t realize it, but soon she will be working as hard as them. Her life is torn apart when her father is killed. Driven from their beautiful home in Mexico, Esperanza and her mother start over in a camp for farm workers in California. It is here where Esperanza must learn to rise again.

    Issues addressed: Immigration, starting over in a new place. This book can spark conversation about what it means to immigrate and how hard it is to adapt to a new setting.

  2. Good Night, Commander by Ahmad Akbarpour

    Grade Level: 3-6

    Synopsis: A young boy who has lost his leg - and his mother - in the war acts out imaginary battles against his enemies, seeking revenge, until he sees that the enemy is young, too, and also has experienced loss.

    Issues addressed: Students with disabilities, dealing with loss. This book can ignite a discussion about how it feels to lose something very dear to you.

  3. The Boy in the Dress by David Williams

    Grade Level: 5-7

    Synopsis: Dennis’s Dad is depressed since his Mom left and his brother is a bully. But at least he has soccer. Then he discovers he enjoys wearing a dress.

    Issues addressed: Gender identity. This book can start a conversation about what “gender norms” are and what gender identity means.

  • Differentiated Instruction Educator's Package, A Differentiated Instruction Implementation Continuum (p. 6), Student Success: Differentiated Instruction Educators’ Package (2010), Ministry of Education and Training

Using this information, identify three differentiation strategies you might use in a junior classroom to help all students be successful learners. Include a brief strategy and its usefulness.

  1. Use various types of media.

    Using different types of media is a great tool for educators to use. First of all, it keeps students interested because it’s not always the same activies/lessons when they come into class. Teachers can use media such as radio, television, movies, magazines, books, iPad apps, etc. in order to better to engage students.

  2. Create instructional activities using multiple intelligences (logical, mathematical, musical, intrapersonal, etc).

    It is important that teachers learn and observe their students learning methods and personalities in order to best plan their lessons. Incorporating activities that all students can excel doing is important for each student’s achievement and confidence.

  3. Give students a choice in learning and assessment activities.

    Students who have an opinion about how they learn are more likely to be fully engaged in their learning. Also, students who have a choice are less likely to act out during class since they are given more responsibility and want to keep those benefits.
Commitment to Students and Student Learn.Useful Feedback:
Useful Feedback Discussion Post & T-Chart

One very important feature of formative assessment is the type of feedback the student receives as they are learning. Often phrases of "good job" and "keep going" are heard in classrooms. These types of phrases, while encouraging, provide no information for students to understand what they have done well or what they need to improve in order to be successful.

Complete a T-Chart that lists familiar "throw-away" phrases often heard in classrooms. (Throw-away phrases are those that do not provide information to the learner). On the other side of the T-chart, provide alternative feedback comments that would be more useful to students.

It is important that we give feedback that outlines student strengths, weaknesses and next steps. We also need to think about the knowledge and skills criteria from the Achievement Charts as it will help us focus on specific aspects of students’ work. When pointing out a weakness and next step, be sure the next step is attainable for the student. This is especially important for students who are on an IEP.

Aboriginal Teaching Strategy: Learning to Unlearn

  • This strategy could be used to teach a grade 5 visual arts lesson. The visual arts lesson would focus on the following specific expectations:

Specific Expectations

  • D1.1 demonstrate an understanding of composition, using selected principles of design to create narrative art works or art works on a theme or topic
  • D1.3 use elements of design in art works to communicate ideas, messages, and understandings
  • D2.3 demonstrate awareness of meaning of signs, symbols and styles in works of art

Procedure

  • With prompting, students make two minds maps - one things that are typically considered beautiful and one for things that are typically not. Students then share with their seating groups some of the ideas that they came up with. Then, using their mind maps and conversations as guides, the students will pick at least one item to draw. However, they will not draw it as it is seen normally, but instead they will create a drawing that depicts the item(s) in the opposite way. So, if its an item that is usually considered beautiful, they will try to convey it as not beautiful and if it is usually considered not beautiful, they will try to convey it as beautiful.
Ongoing Professional Learning.Belief Statement about Junior Learners:
Webquest & Belief Statement Task

In order to build a good foundation of knowledge about the junior student, your first activity will give you an opportunity to explore what the learning theorists have to say about the nature of the learner at this level. Educational researchers have been working for many years to understand how learning occurs and what factors affect learning. Each research perspective provides insight about the learner, but more importantly it provides teachers with information about how to provide meaningful experiences for their students. Knowledge of theories of learning helps teachers come to an understanding about their own beliefs about how children learn.

To gather information about educational theorists, you will engage in an online webquest. To learn more about webquests go to: http://webquest.org/

In this activity, you will take part in a short-term webquest. This is one style of webquest; as you learn more about webquests, you may find others types or ways of displaying information that are more suited to your teaching style.

After reading about the various learning theorists, you will develop a belief statement about teaching and learning for the junior learner based on a learning theory that resonates with you. Belief statements are simply guiding principles that incorporate how your core beliefs about this age group could affect your teaching, particularly how you frame learning experiences.

I believe that at the Junior age group, we need to focus on including all students in our lessons. According to the Erik Erikson, it is important for students to feel a sense of accomplishment in their early development. In order to help each student feel this way, we need to make an effort to learn about our students’ likes and dislikes so that our lessons will engage students. It is also essential that we learn about their strengths and weaknesses so that we can modify our lessons around their specific needs.

I feel comfortable with most technolgies that are available for the classroom. However, for the technologies that I have not experienced before, I would like to believe that I am able to quickly adapt and learn how to use something new.

Technology Uses and Thoughts
SMART Boards The SMART Board has many uses, from a projector for a classroom computer to an interactive station in a center-based classroom. Many times, these boards are not much more than glorified overhead projectors or chalkboards. For the technology to be transformative, teachers need to allow students to use the boards for learning activities, in small groups if possible.
Laptops/Tablets Laptops, Chromebooks or tablets are a great way for students to learn on the move. These are used for everything from simple access to resources for learning, to creating products that demonstrate their learning and understanding in ways that best suit them.
Hardware A well-equiped classroom should have many types of hardware such as microphones and headsets for audio listening and creation, digital cameras (still and video) for students to capture their thoughts and daily learning.
Google Documents This tool allows collaboration between students in a completely new way. When assigning group/partner work, ask the students to put their work into a Google Doc.
Skype Skype is a great way to have students interact with people from outside your area. If it not feasible for guest speakers to visit your school, you can use Skype to have them speak to your class that way instead.
Class Website Starting a class website with general information, homework postings and lesson information is definitely a must-do for every teacher. This platform of communication allows the teacher to post important information for the class
Socrative Socrative is an app/website that lets teachers engage and assess their students with educational activities on tablets, laptops and smartphones. They use real-time questioning, instant result aggregation and visualization to help the teacher guage the whole class' current level of understanding.

Professional Knowledge.Bloom's Taxonomy:
Bloom's Taxonomy Discussion Post

There are many variations of Bloom's Taxonomy. Please visit the following websites to learn more about Bloom's Taxonomy and ways to apply it in your classroom.

  • The Best Resources for Helping Teachers Use Bloom's Taxonomy in the Classroom
  • Bloom's Taxonomy - Learning and Teaching
  • Bloom's Taxonomy - The University of Georgia

Here are other useful resources that offer teaching strategies and tools for fostering thinking skills in the classroom:

  • Asking Effective Questions, from the Literacy and Numeracy Series
  • Being Responsive to Student Thinking, from the Literacy and Numeracy Series
  • Critical Literacy, from the Literacy and Numeracy Series
  • The Critical Thinking Consortium, under Teaching Resources

Review the Achievement Chart criteria for thinking. How can you incorporate some of the ideas from this research into your daily teaching? Choose one idea to explore and share it.

I learned that there are many variations of Bloom's Taxonomy while I was visiting several website to learn about how to apply it in my classroom. Essentially, Bloom's Taxonomy is a classification of learning objectives within education. It divides these objectives into three domains - cognitive, affective and psychomotor (knowing, feeling and doing).

I was able to see some clear and logical connections, after revisiting the achievement charts in the Ontario Curriculum. For example, "remember" and "understand" in the Taxonomy sounds similar to "knowledge and understanding". This leads to "apply" and then "analyze, evaluate, create" which in my opinion, sounds very simliar to our achievement chart in Ontario!
Professional Knowledge.Grade 6 Space Unit Outline:
Grade 6 Space Unit Plan

Read pages 28 to 38 in The Guide to Effective Literacy Instruction: Grades 4 to 6, Volume Three: Planning and Classroom Management

From all the information you have discovered about the curriculum at the junior level, you will need to choose a method of integrating curriculum. Remember that integration is not just about choosing a theme and making it cross-curricular. Think about the article by Nicola Findley to help you in your decision making.

How many expectations go into one unit of study? That is a difficult question to answer with an exact number. One factor is how much time you are allowing for a particular unit in your timetable. If you are doing a cross-curricular unit and have allowed all morning or afternoon for a week or 10 days, this will give you an opportunity to address more expectations than a unit that is taking one period a day for one week.

A second consideration is how the specific expectations are listed in the documents. The specific expectations provide information about the scope of the overall expectations. Is this a brand new topic for students? Is this a topic that is building upon the work done in previous years or in this grade? Is the scope of the topic narrow or broad? What do the specific expectations tell me about the depth that the topic is expected to cover at this grade level?

When designing the unit, you will focus on the overall expectations as the goal and the specific expectations will be the scaffolding you will use to move your students toward that goal.

For this task:

  1. You will select a grade, subject area and a specific unit\topic of study for your unit outline (Eg, Grade 6 Science, Diversity of Living Things).

  2. Then, decide on the cluster of expectations (first overall expectations that work well together and then specific expectations that address the overall expectations) for your unit outline. Be sure to include a rationale for the choices you are making.

  3. Decide on the timeframe.

  4. Over the next two modules, you will be doing some assignments related to the topic and expectations you have chosen.

  5. Looking at your chosen expectations, make notes about which learning skills you will include in your unit, and how you can incorporate any of the valuable messages from the Creating Pathways to Success document.

  6. Consider how you will integrate.

  • Unit Plan Title: Space
  • Grade: 6
  • Subject(s): Science and Technology
  • Term: 2
  • Unit Length: 6-7 weeks
  • Cross-Curricular Connections: Language, Arts

Curriculum Expectations

Overall Expectations
  • assess the impact of space exploration on society and the environment
  • investigate characteristics of the systems of which the earth is a part and the relationship between the earth, the sun, and the moon
  • demonstrate an understanding of components of the systems of which the earth is a part, and explain the phenomena that results from the movement of different bodies in space
Specific Expectations
  1. Relating Science and Technology to Society and the Environment
    1. assess the contributions of Canadians to the exploration and scientific understanding of space
    2. evaluate the social and environmental costs and benefits of space exploration, taking different points of view into account
  2. Developing Investigation and Communication Skills
    1. follow established safety procedures for handling tools and materials and observing the sun
    2. use technological problem-solving skills to design, build and test devices for investigating the motions of different bodies in the solar system
    3. use scientific inquiry/research skills to investigate scientific and technological advances that allow humans to adapt to life in space
    4. use appropriate science and technology vocabulary, including axis, tilt, rotation, revolution, planets, moon, comets, and asteroids, in oral and written communication
    5. use a variety of forms to communicate with different audiences and for a variety of purposes
  3. Understanding Basic Concepts
    1. identify components of the solar system, including the sun, the earth, and other planets, natural satellites, comets, asteroids, and meteoroids, and describe their physical characteristics in qualitative terms
    2. identify the bodies in space that emit light and those that reflect light
    3. explain how humans meet their basic biological needs in space
    4. identify the technological tools and devices need for space exploration
    5. describe the effects of the relative positions and motions of the earth, moon and sun

Shared Reading Literacy Lesson Discussion Post

You can find a lesson plan template at http://www.eworkshop.on.ca. This template is a 5 day lesson plan and your lesson may take less time than this. Please complete the introductory lesson in detail and then give a more general indication of the flow of the topic from that point for subsequent days.
  • Indicate the grade and include specific strategies used.

Title

Spring Summer Autumn Winter by Diane Siebert (Book of 4 Poems)

Key Understandings

The focus of this lesson will be to help students to analyze the use of literary devices such as rhyme, word play, imagery and rhythm and how to compare what they read with their personal experiences.

Assessment

  • Note student involvement during oral discussions
  • Hand in Venn diagram activity

Prior Knowledge

Students will have a basic understanding of poetry and poetry strategies.

Teaching Focus/Curriculum Expectations

Students will:

  • 1.1 Read a variety of texts from diverse cultures, including literacy texts.

  • 1.6 Extend understandings of texts by connecting the ideas to their own knowledge, experience, and insights to other familiar texts, and to the world around them.

  • 2.4 Identify various elements of style – including word choice and the use of similes, personification, comparative adjectives, and sentences of different types, lengths and structures – and explain how they help communicate meaning.

Teaching Strategies

  • Whole group discussion
  • Venn diagram to compare two poems
  • Think-Pair-Share, elbow partners, small groups

Materials/Preparation for Teaching

  • The poems electronically or printed for a SmartBoard or document camera
  • A copy of both poems for each student
  • Copy of a fillable Venn diagram for each student

Instruction - Day 1: Summer (p. 10-15)

Time Frame Instruction
Before Reading Before beginning, tell students to listen to the sounds of the poem. Tell them to take note of the words that the poet chooses. Inform them that poets use different literary devices to create images in the reader’s mind.
During Reading Read "Summer", p 11-13. Make sure you help students observe punctuation as you read. The punctuation also gives the poem its rhythm. It would be a good idea to read the poem in advance (before reading with the class) in order to become familiar with the rhythms and unusual wordplay.

Make sure you help students with challenging vocabulary. Use difficult words from the text in conversation to help students determine a definition that they can understand.
After Reading Once finished reading the poem, highlight the literary devices that the author uses. Examples - rhyming words, alliteration, etc.

Instruction - Day 2: Winter (p. 22-31)

Time Frame Instruction
Before Reading Guide a discussion to help students reflect on the previous poem about summer and brainstorm some of their favourite parts. Then describe what your focus is going to be for the day. Encourage questions and responses from your students throughout the lesson.
During Reading Read "Winter", p 22-31. As you read, get students to reflect on the images that are being created.
After Reading Provide an opportunity for students to discuss any new words or phrases that may have come up in the poem. Ask students to share any experiences they’ve had with winter and if the poem’s images connected with any of their experiences.

Instruction - Day 3: p.11-14, 22-25

Time Frame Instruction
Rereading Introduce the focus for the lesson. Reread p 11-13. Then guide a discussion of the opinions and view of summer that were introduced. Then reread p 22-25. Help guide a discussion about how to compare the poet’s views of summer and winter.
After Reading Create a Venn diagram to demonstrate visual comparisons between the two poems. Guide students to help them understand how using a graphic organizer can help organize their thinking.

You can also pick out a word from the poems to help define and review the meaning of a preposition.

Reflection

Were my students successful? What worked well? What should I change for future lessons?

Professional Practice.Types of Diagnostic Assessment:
Diagnostic Assessment Discussion Post

When beginning a new unit or topic it is valuable to find out the prior knowledge of students the week prior to beginning your new unit. It is very important to have time to adjust the front end of your unit to either compact the material, if students already have a good understanding of the topic, OR to incorporate a review section at the beginning of the unit to build the lead-up to your unit. There is nothing worse than having students who are lost at the beginning of a unit because diagnostic information was not gathered and addressed.

Consider the following questions related to diagnostic assessment:

  • How can you perform diagnostic assessment for your unit of study?
  • What type of task might include parents in a diagnostic assessment?
  • What types of things can you do to adjust the beginning of a unit?

Create a list of ideas about the types of diagnostic assessment that should be used prior to beginning your particular unit. Include suggestions for changes that may need to be made based on data gathered through the diagnostic assessment processes you are proposing.

How can you perform diagnostic assessment for your unit of study?

There are a variety of assessment strategies that are currently used by teachers to evaluate their students’ prior knowledge of a particular subject. Some examples of diagnostic assessments are:

  • Journals
  • Graphic organizers
  • Pre-tests
  • KWL activity
  • Surveys
  • Performance task
  • Mind map
  • Conference
  • Graffiti wall

Within my unit of study, I would use:

  • KWL activity - Ask students to create an organizational tool, in order to indicate what they know, what they want to know and what they have learned. This allows students to reflect back on their original knowledge and comment on their learning process.
  • Journals - The journal activity would allow me to assess their current knowledge before an activity and help formulate changes in future activities.
  • Graffiti Wall - This tool would allow students to start thinking about the language that they will be exposed to, and help me determine their current knowledge of key terms.

What type of task might include parents in a diagnostic assessment?

As mentioned previously, communication with parents is extremely important in order to make sure that each student is supported at school and at home. By providing a diagnostic assessment to parents, it would enable the teacher to communicate the goals that are being set in the classroom, as well as provide an opportunity to receive feedback information that would allow for a more holistic picture of how the student is supported. For my class in particular, I would use hard print and electronic media to send home parent surveys, questionnaires and diagnostic assessment tools.

What types of things can you do to adjust the beginning of a unit?

If the students are further ahead than anticipated:

  • make my first lesson more condensed than original plan and maybe even remove some information that the students already know
  • spend less time on concepts that the students know already, just briefly mention them instead or remove them completely

If the students are further behind than anticipated:

  • add another lesson which is a "review" class
  • have students research information about the missing topics online or in books
